title: Increases the penalties for sexual performances by a child and provides for consecutive sentencing upon certain multiple convictions
summary: Increases the penalties for persons convicted of child pornography; creates a new crime of use of a child in a sexual performance in the first degree and imposes consecutive sentencing upon certain multiple convictions of child pornography statutes.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S1904

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the penal law, in relation to increasing the criminal penalties
for sexual performances by a child and in relation to providing for
consecutive sentencing upon certain multiple convictions

PURPOSE/SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
This bill would amend article 263 of the
penal law to increase penalties for child pornography and to provide
for consecutive sentencing of persons who are found guilty of a child
pornography offense and another crime.

SUMMARY:
Section 1: This bill would amend section 263.00 of the penal
law to change the definitions of "sexual performance" and "obscene
sexual performance" to include sexual conduct by a child less than
eighteen years of age. Presently, the section defines such terms to
include sexual conduct by a child less than sixteen years of age.

Section 2: This bill would also add a new section 263.03 to the penal
law to establish a new crime of use of a child in a sexual
performance in the first degree. A person would be guilty of such
crime, when, knowing the character and content thereof he employs,
authorizes or induces a child less than twelve years of age to engage
in a sexual performance or being a parent, legal guardian or
custodian of such child, consents to the participation by such child
in a sexual performance. The use of a child in a sexual performance in
the first degree would be a class B felony.

Section 3: This bill would further amend section 263.05 of the penal
law to reclassify the current crime of use of a child in a sexual
performance as use of a child in a sexual performance in the second
degree. It would also amend this section to increase the age of the
children protected by this section from children less than sixteen
years of age to children less than eighteen years of age. The conduct
prescribed by the use of a child in a sexual performance in the
second degree would remain a class C felony.

Section 4: This bill would additionally add a new section 263.08 to
the penal law to establish a new crime of promoting an obscene sexual
performance by a child in the first degree. A person would be guilty
of such crime, when, knowing the character and content thereof, he
produces, directs or promotes any obscene performance which includes
sexual conduct by a child less than twelve years of age. promoting an
obscene sexual performance by a child in the first degree would be a
class C felony.

Section 5: This bill would also amend section 263.10 of the penal law to
reclassify the current crime of promoting an obscene sexual

performance by a child as promoting an obscene sexual performance by
a child in the second degree. It would also amend this section to
increase the age of the children protected by this section from
children less than sixteen years of age to children less than
eighteen years of age. The conduct prescribed by the promoting of an
obscene sexual performance by a child in the second degree would
remain a class D felony.

Section 6: This bill would further add a new section 263.13 to the
penal law to establish a new crime of promoting a sexual performance
by a child in the first degree. A person would be guilty of such
crime, when, knowing the character and content thereof, he produces.
directs or promotes any performance which includes sexual conduct by
a child less than twelve years of age. Promoting a sexual performance
by a child in the first degree would be a class C felony.

Section 7: This bill would also amend section 263.15 of the penal law
to reclassify the current crime of promoting a sexual performance by
a child as promoting a sexual performance by a child in the second
degree.
It would also amend this section to increase the age of the children
protected by this section from children less than sixteen years of
age to children less than eighteen years of age. The conduct
prescribed by the promoting of a sexual performance by a child in the
second degree would remain a class D felony.

Section 8: This bill would additionally amend section 263.20 of the
penal law to provide, that under this article the defendant shall
have an affirmative defense if he, in good faith, reasonably believed
that the person appearing in the performance was eighteen years of
age. No such affirmative defense would be available to the defendant,
for the first degree crimes of this article, simply because the
defendant believed the child was between the ages of twelve years and
eighteen.

Section 9: This bill would also amend section 70.25 of the penal law
to provide for sentences of imprisonment to run consecutively .when a
person is convicted of a child pornography crime and any other crime.

Section 10: This bill would take effect on the first day of November
next succeeding the date on which it shall have become a law.

JUSTIFICATION:
Child pornography exploits children, who, as the most
vulnerable members of our society, are most deserving of protection
by our criminal justice system. The current statutory provisions
relating to the use of a child in a sexual performance, and the
promotion of an obscene sexual performance by a child, are
inadequate, drawing no distinction between sexual conduct of children
of different ages nor permitting concurrent sentences. This bill
affords greater protection to children by providing the essential
deterrence to those who seek to use children in sexual performances.

Specifically, new sections of the penal law would be created to
protect children under the age of twelve and would impose a higher
penalty than presently applicable. This bill would also extend
protection to children under the age of eighteen, rather than under
the age of sixteen.

Criminals who exploit children should not be permitted to have their
sentences effectively merged. This bill addresses this issue by requir-
ing that when a defendant is convicted of a child pornography crime,
and any other crime, he must serve consecutive sentences, and not
have his sentences run concurrently. This provision adds an
especially important deterrent to child pornographers, since the very
nature of their activity, more often than not, leads them to commit
multiple criminal acts. Under a system of consecutive sentencing,
such a criminal will be held responsible for all his criminal acts,
and not just one of them. There is no more heinous act than a crime
which is committed against society's most innocent members, our
children. It is imperative to our society's future to protect all of
our children and afford them every opportunity to become productive
and well-adjusted members of our society.

Child pornography degrades our children and our entire society to its
lowest possible level. This bill would take the necessary measures to
protect our children from those who would scar and exploit them for
their own warped gratification or profit. It would also send a strong
message that New York is not a state that will tolerate this
activity, and that we will enact appropriate penalties that fit the
seriousness of this crime.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act would take effect on the first date of
November next succeeding the date it shall become law.
